image.altText: Katherine Goodall wears scrubs and holds a gift while pregnant

items.synopsis: A young mum has qualified as a surgeon despite a shock bowel cancer diagnosis part way through her training.

title.children: Young surgeon's shock bowel discovery highlights growing under 50s cancer risk

image.altText: a woman looking at facebook marketplace on a computer

items.synopsis: Ever sold something on Facebook Marketplace or Gumtree? Without knowing it, you might've put yourself in danger. Here's how to stay safe when selling items online.

title.children: Seller beware: How putting up items for sale on Facebook Marketplace and Gumtree could put you at risk

image.altText: Heather Anderson portrait

items.synopsis: Adelaide premiership player Heather Anderson is the first known professional female athlete to be diagnosed with the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).

title.children: 'Highly significant': First professional female athlete diagnosed with CTE in landmark case

image.altText: The burnt remains of a 4WD vehicle, in darkness.

items.synopsis: Crime scenes have been established to identify skeletal remains discovered in separate cars overnight.

title.children: Two bodies found in separate burnt-out cars in Sydney, as crime scenes set up

image.altText: British PM Rishi Sunak cheers while at an Ashes Test at Lord's.

items.synopsis: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak backs up the England cricket team in their complaints about the dismissal of Jonny Bairstow.

title.children: Not upheld the spirit of cricket: UK PM attacks Australia over controversial Ashes moment

image.altText: A bearded man in front of a river wearing a wide brim hat slightly smiling at the camera

items.synopsis: Ray Burgess was diagnosed with advanced cancer but didn't receive treatment for months due to long outpatient waitlists and lack of specialised equipment.

title.children: Ray's GP told him he had colon cancer in December. He couldn't begin treatment until May, and by June he was dead

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: With the economy slowing, inflation pressures easing and household expenditure diving, starting the new financial year with hike number 13 could well prove to be an ominous sign, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Abandon all logic — whether the RBA pauses rates comes down a coin toss

image.altText: woman in front of muddy truck and caravan near Birdsville.

items.synopsis: Big Red Bash organisers say the journey to one of the world's most remote music festivals is all part of the experience, but many travellers got more than they bargained for on the way to this year's event.

title.children: Road closures, muddy chaos for travellers heading to Birdsville's Big Red Bash

image.altText: letter boxes falling over

items.synopsis: Former Dyldam bosses Fayad Fayad and Remon Fayad, and their father Sam Fayad, are behind apartment blocks across Sydney slapped with sanctions from the NSW Building Commissioner.

title.children: Serious defects in Sydney unit blocks linked to family of property developers as owners wait to move in

image.altText: Aircraft sit at the gates of Darwin International Airport.

items.synopsis: Jetstar flights between Darwin and Denpasar have been put on hold, as work by the Australian Defence Department places the plans of Top End travellers in jeopardy.

title.children: Flight sales to Bali are being pulled in northern Australia's hottest months. What's going on?

image.altText: A man wearing a black jacket, plaid shirt and black beanie holds an acoustic guitar.

items.synopsis: What started off as a casually recorded folk song became a foundational entry in the Australian songbook.

title.children: It began with some chords strummed around a camp fire. It became an Australian music legacy

image.altText: a collage of four people

items.synopsis: Business owners along Mary Street know the natural disaster will strike again — but say the risk is worth it.

title.children: Gympie's historic main street has flooded 12 times in 150 years, but business owners keep coming back

image.altText: A photo of a car being driven at night with a blurry night trail.

items.synopsis: Victoria's road toll is at a 12-year high. A driver, who spent time in jail after he killed another person while speeding, shares his story in the hope others don't make a similar mistake.

title.children: 'Anthony' made an impulsive decision to speed and it cost another driver their life

image.altText: A composite image of Novak Djokovic and Jordan Thompson

items.synopsis: Jordan Thompson produces a comeback win for the ages at Wimbledon, with his reward a shot at defending champion Novak Djokovic.

title.children: Aussie's Wimbledon epic gets him showdown with Djokovic

image.altText: A person's blurred shoulder as they walk past a PWC logo.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to start its day relatively flat ahead of a potential interest rate hike from the Reserve Bank, while Wall Street closed marginally higher. Follow live.

title.children: PwC completes $1 sale of government advisory business, RBA interest rate decision looms, ASX to open flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Embattled consulting firm PwC has signed an agreement to sell its government advisory business for $1 to private equity firm Allegro Funds. However, it expects to spend more than $100 million in "employment and operational costs". The new entity will be called Scyne Advisory, and have around 1,750 ex-PwC staff. In a statement, Allegro said the new business will be "fully independent" of PwC. In recent months, PwC has been caught up in a damaging tax scandal. It led to eight senior partners being forced out, government departments refusing to extend their consulting contracts with the firm, and its senior management being grilled before Senate inquiries. The scandal involved a senior partner using secret information it obtained (about the government plan's to tax multinational companies), working out a loophole to get around them and selling the plan to those companies, making millions of dollars in fees. Some commentors have compared PwC's conduct as simliar to a 'double agent'. "Scyne Advisory will establish an independent Board of Directors to oversee a rigorous, ASX-standard of governance and integrity in the business," Allegro said. To allay concerns about the integrity of the new business, Allegro has hired former Federal Court judge Andrew Greenwood to join the board as a non-executive director. Allegro said it expects the deal to be finalised by the end of August.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Allegro buys PwC's government for $1, renaming it 'Scyne Advisory'

children.content: Embattled consulting firm PwC has signed an agreement to sell its government advisory business for $1 to private equity firm Allegro Funds.
However, it expects to spend more than $100 million in "employment and operational costs".
The new entity will be called
Scyne Advisory
, and have around 1,750 ex-PwC staff.
In a statement, Allegro said the new business will be "fully independent" of PwC.
In recent months, PwC has been caught up in a damaging tax scandal.
It led to eight senior partners being forced out, government departments refusing to extend their consulting contracts with the firm, and its senior management being grilled before Senate inquiries.

The scandal involved a senior partner using secret information it obtained (about the government plan's to tax multinational companies), working out a loophole to get around them and selling the plan to those companies, making millions of dollars in fees.
Some commentors have compared PwC's conduct as simliar to a 'double agent'.
"Scyne Advisory will establish an independent Board of Directors to oversee a rigorous, ASX-standard of governance and integrity in the business," Allegro said.
To allay concerns about the integrity of the new business, Allegro has hired former Federal Court judge Andrew Greenwood to join the board as a non-executive director.
Allegro said it expects the deal to be finalised by the end of August.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's what economists from Australia's major financial instituations are saying. Basically, it's getting harder to predict what the Reserve Bank will do. Shane Oliver (AMP Capital, chief economist): "It’s a very close call but on balance we expect that the RBA will raise the cash rate again on Tuesday by another 0.25% taking it to 4.35%. "The lower-than-expected May CPI [consumer price index] provides scope for another pause. "We continue to think that the RBA has already done enough with inflation already falling and that it’s not paying enough attention to the lags with which monetary policy impacts the economy which runs the now very high risk of tipping us into recession." Jarek Kowcza (St George, senior economist): "While we acknowledge that it is likely to be another ‘finely balanced’ decision, we think the scales are tilted towards another 25-basis-point hike this month. "Financial market pricing implies that there is a good chance of two more hikes (i.e. to 4.60%) before we reach the terminal rate, with a peak rate of 4.53% priced by the end of 2023. "However, markets are uncertain around when these hikes are likely to be delivered." Rodrigo Catril (NAB, senior foreign exchange strategist): "NAB expects the RBA to raise the cash rate to 4.6% in the months ahead, having pencilled in 25bps [basis points] hikes in July and August. "The data flow argues that the RBA should hike on Tuesday, with little value in waiting for more data. "Saying that, the decision is likely to be as evenly balanced as it was last month, and it would not be a surprise if the RBA chose to hold fire at this meeting in anticipation of the full quarterly CPI [consumer price index] and SoMP [statement on monetary policy] forecast update." Belinda Allen, CBA senior economist "In what is likely to be another finely balanced decision, we expect the RBA to leave the cash rate on hold at 4.10% in July, pausing before one final rate hike in August. "The RBA has stated that the June meeting was finely balanced, with the rate hike driven by upside inflation risks. "The lower than expected monthly CPI print for May has, in our view, tilted the balance of risks to an on hold decision in July. "But the July RBA Board meeting remains ‘live’ given the RBA’s tightening bias and heighted concerns over inflation risks. "We attach a 60% probability of on hold decision at the July RBA Board meeting, with a 40% chance of a 25bp hike."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: To hike or not to hike ... that is the question for the RBA

children.content: Here's what economists from Australia's major financial instituations are saying.
Basically, it's getting harder to predict what the Reserve Bank will do.
Shane Oliver (AMP Capital, chief economist):
"It’s a very close call but on balance we expect that the RBA will raise the cash rate again on Tuesday by another 0.25% taking it to 4.35%.
"The lower-than-expected May CPI [consumer price index] provides scope for another pause.

"We continue to think that the RBA has already done enough with inflation already falling and that it’s not paying enough attention to the lags with which monetary policy impacts the economy which runs the now very high risk of tipping us into recession."
Jarek Kowcza (St George, senior economist):
"While we acknowledge that it is likely to be another ‘finely balanced’ decision, we think the scales are tilted towards another 25-basis-point hike this month.
"Financial market pricing implies that there is a good chance of two more hikes (i.e. to 4.60%) before we reach the terminal rate, with a peak rate of 4.53% priced by the end of 2023.
"However, markets are uncertain around when these hikes are likely to be delivered."
Rodrigo Catril (NAB, senior foreign exchange strategist):
"NAB expects the RBA to raise the cash rate to 4.6% in the months ahead, having pencilled in 25bps [basis points] hikes in July and August.
"The data flow argues that the RBA should hike on Tuesday, with little value in waiting for more data.

"Saying that, the decision is likely to be as evenly balanced as it was last month, and it would not be a surprise if the RBA chose to hold fire at this meeting in anticipation of the full quarterly CPI [consumer price index] and SoMP [statement on monetary policy] forecast update."
Belinda Allen, CBA senior economist
"In what is likely to be another finely balanced decision, we expect the RBA to leave the cash rate on hold at 4.10% in July, pausing before one final rate hike in August.
"The RBA has stated that the June meeting was finely balanced, with the rate hike driven by upside inflation risks.
"The lower than expected monthly CPI print for May has, in our view, tilted the balance of risks to an on hold decision in July.
"But the July RBA Board meeting remains ‘live’ given the RBA’s tightening bias and heighted concerns over inflation risks.
"We attach a 60% probability of on hold decision at the July RBA Board meeting, with a 40% chance of a 25bp hike."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's latest business and economic news. The local share market is likely to start its day relatively flat, after a quiet session on Wall Street (which closed two early hours early ahead of its Independence Day public holiday). The S & P 500 gained 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2% and the Dow Jones index was steady. Tesla was one of the best-performers, after its share price jumped 6.9%. The electric car maker said it delivered a record number of vehicles in the June quarter (beating market estimates). The Elon Musk-led company handed 466,140 vehicles in the April to June period (up 10% from the preceding quarter, and 83% higher from a year earlier). These numbers from Tesla are the closest approximation of its sales figures, and are closely watched by analysts and shareholders. The Australian dollar is relatively steady at 66.7 US cents, and its movements today will be affected by what the Reserve Bank decides with interest rates this afternoon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to open flat, Wall Street steady as Tesla shares jump

children.content: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's latest business and economic news.
The local share market is likely to start its day relatively flat, after a quiet session on Wall Street (which closed two early hours early ahead of its Independence Day public holiday).
The S
P 500 gained 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2% and the Dow Jones index was steady.
Tesla was one of the best-performers, after its share price jumped 6.9%.
The electric car maker said it delivered a record number of vehicles in the June quarter (beating market estimates).
The Elon Musk-led company handed 466,140 vehicles in the April to June period (up 10% from the preceding quarter, and 83% higher from a year earlier).
These numbers from Tesla are the closest approximation of its sales figures, and are closely watched by analysts and shareholders.
The Australian dollar is relatively steady at 66.7 US cents, and its movements today will be affected by what the Reserve Bank decides with interest rates this afternoon.

image.altText: An Ezidi woman stands in front of a library sign at Armidale library.

items.synopsis: Persecuted in their home country, Ezidi refugees say their language is being ignored in Australia — with negative impacts on their health care.

title.children: Health care lost in translation as refugees wait '12 hours in the emergency room'

image.altText: A cricket player in whites carries a protester off the ground.

items.synopsis: After a string of recent high-profile environmental protests at sporting events, Formula 1 drivers warn that a similar disruption at this weekend's British Grand Prix could put lives at risk.

title.children: 'It is a stupid thing to do': Lando Norris warns protesters not to repeat Ashes protest at British F1 GP

image.altText: Man in cowboy hat standing in front of horses in a yard.

items.synopsis: Pastoralist George Scott has been watching how his neighbours fared with sheep and is now thinking about diversifying. A wool judge, meanwhile, has declared this season the best he's ever seen.

title.children: Wool so good in outback Queensland, this cattle king is thinking about giving sheep a go

image.altText: A projected image of a chimpanzee eating something green with a silhouette of a man next to it

items.synopsis: Australian scientists have found a way to remotely measure the heart rates of chimpanzees using a digital camera and artificial intelligence. It's hoped the contact-free technique will help detect cardiac disease in the species.

title.children: Like humans, chimpanzees can get heart disease. Now AI could help detect it

image.altText: A soldier waves a Ukrainian flag with his right hand as he holds a rifle in his left hand while standing atop a concrete block.

items.synopsis: While many fret about the "slowness" of the Ukrainian campaign, all military operations consist of pulses and pauses and there is much we do not see in this war. It is important to remain patient, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's war campaign may seem 'slow', but its military strategy is full of surprises — and Russia could be in deep trouble

image.altText: A plant in a red pot with an animated face.

items.synopsis: When Francesco needs water, sunlight, or even company, he can talk to let his owner know. It wouldn't be that impressive, except he's a plant pot.

title.children: 'The invisible lives of plants': Hopes smart pot will create deeper connection between house plants and owners

image.altText: Old man with grey hair and button up shirt

items.synopsis: John Kerr was found unconscious on a popular walking track two weeks ago and died at the scene with serious head injuries.

title.children: Man charged with murder of 87-year-old Noosa man allegedly attacked on morning walk

image.altText: the president of indonesia arrives at an airport as he is greeted by officials

items.synopsis: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has arrived in Australia in what some hope will lead to "concrete" agreements between the neighbouring countries on energy, security and trade.

title.children: Indonesian president's visit presents chance for 'concrete actions' with Australia, expert says

image.altText: Chief Superintendent of Police Li Kwai-wah speaks during a press conference.

items.synopsis: An Australian citizen is among eight overseas-based activists who have been accused by Hong Kong police of national security offences, including foreign collusion and incitement to secession.

title.children: Australian lawyer has $190k reward offered against him by Hong Kong authorities

image.altText: Police released photo of missing person Jarrod Davies.

items.synopsis: A 27-year-old Melbourne man was served 23 drinks at two waterfront venues in Hobart before falling into the water where his body was found two days later, an inquest hears.

title.children: 'Something wasn't right': Man who drowned on Hobart waterfront served 23 drinks, inquest hears

image.altText: Kevin Spacey arrives at a London court wearing a tie.

items.synopsis: An accuser labels Kevin Spacey "slippery and sick" and says the actor tried to groom him, allegations the actor denies.

title.children: Spacey assaults 'made me feel sick', accuser tells London court

image.altText: A police officer stands next to burnt out cars.

items.synopsis: As France continues to face civil unrest, a fundraiser for the police officer who shot dead a teenager at a traffic stop causes new divisions.

title.children: 'Playing with fire': Fundraiser for French policeman who killed teen raises millions

image.altText: Margot Robbie wears a pink jacket and headpiece in front of a pink and white background.

items.synopsis: State media reports Vietnam has banned the Barbie movie over a scene featuring a map that shows China's unilaterally claimed territory in the South China Sea.

title.children: Vietnam bans Barbie movie over scene featuring South China Sea map

image.altText: A collection of maneki-neko or lucky cat statues.

items.synopsis: Maneki-neko — otherwise known as lucky cats or welcoming cats — are found around the world. But where the ceramic cats began to be sold remains a mystery, writes Tets Kimura.

title.children: They're now found behind cash registers all over the world, but where did the beckoning cat come from?

image.altText: An assortment of skydivers in a circlular formation, linked by arms and legs, free-fall towards the dry ground below.

items.synopsis: A record-holding Australian skydiver has been killed in an accident in Texas while doing the sport she loved, her mother says.

title.children: Record-holding Australian skydiver dies in US 'doing what she loved'

image.altText: A brightly lit office reception, with brown wooden desk on a blue carpet and gold trim on walls with twitter logo.

items.synopsis: An Australian business is the latest in an ever-growing list of companies taking Elon Musk's Twitter to court over alleged unpaid bills after the US billionaire paid $US44 billion for the social media platform last year.

title.children: Australian company suing Twitter for more than $1m over alleged unpaid bills, rents

image.altText: A man stands holding a walking stick in front of a wall that has two black cut outs of soldiers on it.

items.synopsis: Leon Gautier was one of 177 French green berets who stormed the Normandy beaches defended by Hitler's forces in 1944.

title.children: France's last surviving D-Day commando dies aged 100
